reviewText:
unfortunately, i cannot recommend this game for the people who want to feel a good game experience. for the fans out there, go and buy it! you will like it despite these important setbacks. so, let's start:

the game is obviously meant for xbox not for pc. game controls and camera angles-movements truly annoying. if you do not have a xbox controller for pc then you will truly feel the frustration.

the game is short. don't get me wrong. i am not complaining about it. i don't judge a game by its length. but my point is, this shortness causes the game to get difficult in a fast pace. it does not give you a chance to get use to the control mechanics. you have to learn those mechanics while getting beaten up unless you want to play the previous chapters for practice. this would not be a problem if the game had a decent save/checkpoint system.

however, the game has one of the worst save/chechpoint systems ever. when you die, you start from the previous checkpoint with all the things you have done are undone. you broke all the vases and gained spirit points? now you die and have to do it again. you found a secret stash through a series of jumping and action movements? now you die and have to do it again!

the game lacks variety of enemies. this makes you feel truly empty. for example, the elemental masters, which you fight as end chapter bosses at the previous level, spawn like common enemies and they attack in groups. for me, this kind of strategy is the cheapest trick in the game development book. when i confront and kill/deal with a boss-like enemy, i want him to stay that way unless scenario has a plot-twist event or something like that. also, reducing bosses to the level of a common grunt?  it just kills the joy and credibility of the game.

beyond these points, game is decent. i like the music, art, graphics and story.

i have to say, i am not a fan of legend of korra (the show). the first avatar series were better than this pro-steampunk setup. legend of korra tries to dictate a kind of westernized style and pushes away the mystic air of the ancient east. and i don't like it.

as a result, this game is surely made for the fans out there. so if you are not a fan, then try to reconsider your thoughts about buying this game.

reviewText:
Not as bad as some gaming outlets would like you to believe, but still a big disappointment - Especially considering that Platinum Games was behind it.

While the game can be quite fun later on (or on a second playthrough), it takes way too much time for it's combat system to become remotely rewarding - If only you started with more bending styles and/or combos unlocked...

The Pro-Bending Championship minigame was actually what I enjoyed the most about TLOK. The mechanics are simple, but solid. The interactions between Korra and her team-mates are also quite amusing - This actually made me wonder why you have so little contact with those characters you know and love during the main campaign.

There are far better hack-and-slash titles out there, so TLOK is a game I'd only recommend to fans of the series, but lets face it: Chances are that if you are a fan, you probably already bought it...

reviewText:
This game was an averagely fun game to play. However, if you're going to get this game and you have an Xbox One / PS4...get it on the console. The PC version is highly buggy. For example, everytime you enter a battlezone where a big fight will happen, the time it takes for the game to introduce the characters to when you actually start fighting takes ridiculous amounts of excess time that just makes the game feel slow (if you did not understand that: when the characters jump onto the screen for battle, they remain static after they have done their showoff moves for around 10-15 seconds. This does not happen in the console version). Also, on a side note, the main boss is almost impossible to beat. The game unforutanely has many bosses that are under the guise of being challenging, but it turns out that they're just really, really cheap. Did you struggle to fight that humongous spirit boss in the beginning of the level? Rest assured, there will be 2 of them that you need to fight at the same time and they'll eclipse your camera, and also there will be environmental hazards.

However, on the bright side:
The combat system is one of the best systems I've ever had the pleasure of playing.
The transition between each of the four elements is very smooth and fluid, and it makes it feel like you're the actual Avatar. It's really great. Also, when you're kicking butt in this game, it feels so amazing. You just feel like you're wrecking everyone, and when you're in the Avatar State it's just chaos.

All in all, throughout the bugs and stuff, the game is good.

7.2/10

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game for any fans of the Avatar: The Last Airbender/Legend of Korra series.

The story feels like an episode of the show (spoiler warnings for the finale of Season 2, but fans should have already seen it by now) and all of the original voice actors are here for their respective roles. The combat feels pretty good and each bending style feels unique and suited for different situations (Waterbending for long-range combat, Earthbending for close-range combat, Firebending for fast, rapid attacks, and Airbending for balanced AoE attacks); and the Naga Running portions feel like a nice, quick break from the combat.

There's not too many unlockables and there's not a whole lot of replay value outside of the Pro-Bending mode (which I think could have been really cool as a PvP multiplayer mode) and a progressively higher difficulty on the main story.

Still, you get a chance to play as the Avatar (suitably kick-♥♥♥ Avatar State included) and it's only $15.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
While this game is repetitive and unforgiving to those not well versed in the action beat-em-up genre, especially those from Platinum Games, this game is a sight to behold and when it’s good, it’s oh so good! I didn’t think it was possible but Bending seamlessly made the transition from animation to game. Every element feel unique and viable and while you can lean on your favourite the game gently encourages you to tactfully pick a style that better suits your opponents.

While the foes you recalled from the show are faithfully rendered it’s the variety of enemies that is lacking, the mooks come in different colours to designate which type of attack they’ll use but there’s only a handful of them. Don’t look for surprises (well, until the end…), this game is as straightforward as Korra herself; keep punching and kicking till you’re the only one left standing.

What stands out however is the game’s “soul”, this could’ve easily been an episode of the show, perhaps spread out over a two-partner of dare I say an actual Book, it’s great to see more of Korra fulfilling her duty as the Avatar and excelling at keeping the peace. Every part of the game feels like it was sketched by animators, the music is just as nostalgic and little things like Iroh’s shop where you can buy items to enhance Korra’s abilities are truly endearing.

The cherry on the top has to be addition of a Pro Bending minigame; if you ever dreamed of seeing how you’d fare in command of the Fire Ferrets well, here’s your chance. Platinum Games are masters of flamboyant combat and they don’t disappoint here; you block, weave and counter as you Bend your way to the top of leagues, there’s even a chance to fight the Wolf Bats!

All in all; if you’re a fan of the series and a decent gamer you can scrape buy on casual but lovers of 3D action games will find a small gem with a healthy layer of sheen and heart.

Wait till you experience the Avatar State, oh my…

reviewText: This game is an action/beat 'em up based on the Nickelodeon cartoon series, The Legend of Korra. It is centered towards fans of Platinum Games and fans of The Legend of Korra. If you're a fan of either or both, I would recommend you buy this game. Otherwise, wait for a sale.\n\nGameplayControls are simple, however, it is best played with a controller. Movement with Korra is fairly fluid, and canceling between attacks/dodges/jumps/counters is effortless because the window is very lenient. Despite this, the game is difficult enough that you can't just mash the same button over and over and get through the game. You will need to employ the use of counters and dodges to be successful, not to mention utilizing the appropriate element for the given situation. Counter-ing is done in a similar vain to the Batman Arkham games where the enemy turning red is your cue to press the counter/block button. As you play through the game, you gain spirit points which you can spend in the spirit shop to buy items/talismans/consumables that either provide a new move or augment your abilities. Sprinkled throughout the game are Temple Run" segments where you ride Naga from point A to point B

reviewText:
If you're a fan of the animated series, then be prepared for a disappointingly useless story.
Not that it's bad, it's just basically non-existent.
Essentially, an old guy takes your bending, you go kick his ♥♥♥.
Oops, spoiler alert.
To be honest, I was expecting a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ story. They also messed that up in Metal Gear Rising (MGS fan here).

But if you think you can handle that, it's alright in the gameplay department.
Not great, but alright.
The concept certainly had A LOT more potential than this but from what I undertand, platinum had a pretty limited budget and development time with this.
So considering that and the price of the game, I can't really call it terrible.

If you're NOT a fan of the animated series and you were just looking for specticle fighters, then you really should play something else instead.
There are better specticle fighters out there (even by the same devs).

reviewText:
Being a huge fan of the cartoon show, it was a given to buy the game without giving it a second thought. And I was not disappointed.

Thanks to Deep Silver it plays like a AAA title. Leveling up elements, buying and unlocking new combos, blocking and counter attacking? Everything's in there! Including the thing you always wanted to do: Being the friggin' Avatar and bending all the elements!

I was a rather avid action adventure / beat 'em up player, but Korra's difficulty surprised me. You really got to keep a cool head, block and counter, otherwise your going down... and that was only NORMAL... so I'll have some fun" playing extreme. :)

Graphics-wise you'll feel the somewhat low budget. Background textures and level design are not too great but they definitely work. Assuming they wanted to make the game feel as close as possible like the cartoon
date: they accomplished that. It looks and feels like you play an episode or two of the cartoon. Also adding animated sequences especially made for the game is a nice treat.\n\nLastly the Pro-Bending. It's kind of an artificial game-time-lengthener
recommended: but it plays well. It just feels as fierce as the matches in the cartoon looked and the difficulties above rookie definitely will show you no mercy. Max out your waterbending or you'll be crushed! ;) A online multiplayer would have been amazing but I guess the budget wasn't enough. Maybe if this one sells well
hoursPlayed: there'll be another one like this? A bigger more adventurous one? Who knows?\n\nI'm totally biased towards the show
voteText: but trying to give it an objective score I'd say 8/10.\nThere are definitely things that could have been made better (graphics- and gameplay-wise) and probably people who don't know the show or cartoons in general won't be too interested in this game. But maybe Korra will get a bunch of new fans through this? Let's hope so!"

reviewText: A very short game, but worth every penny you spent on it.\n\nHonestly, this game didn't have much to say for it (just wait, I'm getting there), when you think about it, it was short, the enemies were the same, and the fighting was awful. BWAHAHAHHA, as if! Don't get me wrong, the other two were right, this game is very short with only ___ chapters (now whats the fun if i tell you go play it yourself) and the enemies were the same throughout the entire game. But platinum always does it right, this game never gets boring. I've replayed it for the 5th time, and I still don't want to stop. Does it disappoint me that there's no online bending vs mode? Yes, does it disappoint me that the story isn't longer? Yes, but despite everything else, for 15 dollars, whether you like Legend of Korra or not, this game will grab you and take hold of you. With the different combinations you can do and the four different types of bendings, this game is limitless. I will honestly never get tired of this game, and it was 15 bucks!!!! Now that's a great game.

reviewText:
This is a tentative recommendation. TL;DR, it's a competent, brawly platformer that's light on story but has a great visual style and challenging gameplay. Despite a fair few issues, it's worth the low price.

The longer version:
The story will make no sense whatsoever if you've not seen the first two seasons of the TV show. Even if you have seen it, you'll be left disappointed by how shallow and meaningless it is. Now that the cartoons have finished (sadly, it seems, indefinitely), this is a one last fix" that will scratch the itch for more Avatar
date: but never fully satisfy the addiction.\n\nThe combat is where the game shines
recommended: but try it on casual difficulty first. On normal
hoursPlayed:
it becomes punishing and frustrating when you just can't get that millisecond chance to counter an incoming attack. Over and over again. For a full ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hour.

The game takes frequent breaks from the scrapping to play a Temple Run-style minigame where you ride Naga (a giant Polar Bear/Dog hybrid) through the streets of Republic City. I hated these sections; your mileage may vary.

To conclude
voteText: the game's low price point reflects it's limitations. Worth a play if you've not quite got over the TV show yet
helpfulPercent: but safe to skip otherwise."

reviewText:
I'd recommend this to people who like and watch The Legend of Korra series on Nicktoons.


PEOPLE WHO WOULD LIKE THE GAME:
The Legend of Korra fans would like the game mainly because that you get to become a bender in it. However, they might be very disappointed because their favorite characters might not be in the game (I don't know if that might of been a minor spoiler to some people or not). This is a low-budget game but I think that graphics fit well with the cartoon.

LAYOUT OF GAME:
The enemies are pretty casual and I don't understand why some certain enemies would appear in certain places. In addition, some cutscenes are all that exiting or necessary. Sometimes, the game is a good way to deal with stress because of how many times you can beat up enemies in an awesome and rewarding way.

CONCLUSION:
What I like the best is that I get to be the bender in the Legend of Korra world and I find that very fun since I've watched the cartoon. So I would give this a 7/10.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
The game overall I would have to rate a 7/10. I'll discuss with the pros and cons of what brought me to this rating.

Pros: Graphics 8.5/10
The developers did a very good job and making the art of the game feel like it was the TV show's animation. It was very impressive and sort of nostalgic to see a beloved series/franchise brought to life. Granted this game was no graphics intensive piece of work, but the graphics to do not make the game.
Voice Over 10/10
The Avatar franchise has done a very good job in casting their voice over team. However I feel like where they missed an opportunity for this game was by limiting the characters we all know and love in the series from being present in the story, however that's a point to be made in the story section of this review. Overall the voice actors did an amazing job at transferring their characters into this video game.
Animations 8/10
Could I have put this in with graphics? Yeah I probably could, but it's the attention to detail that matters here. Being a martial artist of sorts, it was really cool to see each bending style be distincly different. All of the fighting stances were different and displayed the influence of the martial art that the particular bending style was using. The move sets played off of that as well which made it pretty cool to watch your combos as you switched between the elements.

Cons: Game Mechanics 5/10
This may just be me but I feel like the controls for this game weren't as smooth as they could have been. This can especially be said for the Pro-Bending mode, I felt like I struggled the most on the opening level with the Pro-Bending match than I did for the regular platforming levels. I am also going to account for the difficulty mode in this. When I first played this I set the difficulty to Normal, over the other choice which was Casual. The difficulty here was not what I expected and found myself being more frustrated at a Normal" difficulty than I really shoul have been
date: and because of this I feel as if my enjoyment of the game was greatly hindered.\nStory 5/10\nFor both series
recommended: The Last Airbender and Legend of Korra

reviewText:
This is a fairly simple brawler decently paced and decently ballanced once you get the hang of the combo and block/counter systems niether of which are overly complicated but may take a little while to get the hang of.

The art style looks great and true to the show

The final boss fight is a frustrating mix of cheap tricks and mostly unblockable attacks, but the rest of the game flows well.

On easiest difficulty (my first play through in most games is on easiest while I learn the game then I play the harder modes) I beat it in one day, and look forward to the harder challange..

The fights can get a little repetative, and it could be played with button mashing, but the combo system does open new and interesting bending techniques.

When you level up a bending style it adds a health restoration, this combined with the differing items available in the ingame shop lead to interesting strategy options that you CAN dig into but this game is approachable to casual games just fine.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
If you're a big fan of the show you probably already own this game. To everyone else, I don't recommend this game. You really do get what you pay for. Metal Gear Rising is a much better game and chances are you can pick it up for just as cheap. Everything about this game screams budget title.

Mechanically the game is average. Combos are very simple and there are only a handful of command moves. The camera is alright most of the time but against larger enemies or up against tall walls, the camera will position itself poorly and it will often cost you. Targeting is ok. The auto lock on works most of the time, really only getting confused against enemies at range.

Visually the game isn't very impressive. The cell shaded graphics are average. If you're familiar with the show you'll recognise some of the enemy designs. Compared to other games in the genre, the enemy designs are dull. Same can be said about the environments.

There's roughly 4-5 hours worth of content, 10 if you're willing to play again at the highest difficulty. Pro-bending mode is very shallow, and requires you to grind bending levels in the story mode to improve performance there. The story is a throw away. Nothing is developed.

Everything about this game screams budget title. It's hard to look past the repetitive enemies, the bland levels, the bad plot, when the gameplay is mediocre. Play Metal Gear Revengence or Devil May Cry instead.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
****1/2
4.5 out of 5
My favourite video game. Ever.

Based on one of my favourite ever TV shows, Legend of Korra is happily the game I have most enjoyed out of the years I've spent gaming. but I'm not going to hold bias on my review, as although I love this game to pieces(!), it certainly isn't perfect.

Just like the TV show, the game centres around Korra, an avatar that can bend all the major four elements: Earth, Wind, Fire and Air. The game mostly distances itself from the TV show plots with a completely new antagonist - which is welcome and good for newcomers of the series.

The game plays out as a fighter of sorts, although there is collecting and various minigames to be done as well. The game is also very replayable, with different difficulty levels and game modes unlocked after you progress through one round of the game.

As before I say the game isn't perfect, as there are some decidedly high difficulty spikes at times, but regardless I absolutely adore this game, and if you're interested in Platinum, the Korra series or just a good video game in general, you should definitely pick this up. Now.

reviewText:
It's a 15 dollar game. Don't go in expecting a 60 dollar AAA title and you will not be disappointed. The game is geared towards fans of the show and on that I believe it delivers. The story is mostly non-existent (what is there does not make a lot of sense), there aren't as many combos as there could be, the worlds occasionally feel a bit 'empty' aside from enemies. So there are flaws and it could be improved.

Above all though it's just... fun. You will be challenged. In fact I recommend playing with the 1/2 health 2x exp and 1/2 attack 2x exp items. They will increase the challenge and the reward. There may be fights you need to redo repeatedly as you figure out the best strategy to win. There is an extreme mode available once you beat the game as well. I have beaten extreme mode as well, it's mostly a fun challenge. Except for one section where you it takes hundreds of hits to kill the enemy but if they hit you once you will die. I spent a good 2-3 hours of my 15 hour play time just getting past that section in extreme mode (which is relatively easier in normal mode)

The pro-bending matches are also pretty fun. The matches do take skill, and Mako and Bolin are usually not as good as the enemy AI even at MAX bending levels (though occasionally they do save your butt).

There are quite a few unlockables in the game and the trophies are not ridiculous to get so if you've got 15 bucks and you like Avatar then I highly recommend this game.

reviewText: The Legend of Korra is not a perfect game... but it's the darn best Avatar game to date. For the price, you get exactly what you paid for. I think that fans of Korra will be the ones who get the most out of the game and it shows. Sure, the story is a little lacking but the writers had to hold back so it wouldn't have many major impacts on the show. This game is all about letting you be Korra, aka the Avatar! It's a decent fighting game at it's core and you can't get away with just button mashing. There was a lot of effort and care put into this game and despite some of it's faults I'd highly reccomend it. Again it's not a top notch fighter like Bayonetta, but it's a fun little romp in the Avatar Universe (with lots of game over screens)

reviewText: I'm a bit of a Musou fan, and a bit of a Korra fan. Combine the two, and you have my attention. I was expecting a fun time wasting game, and what I got was a fun enough time wasting game that I found myself actually enjoying the light grind to unlock everything. The Extreme mode is definitely not as hardcore as fans (as esoteric as they may be) of Musou games would expect, but still interesting enough that it thoroughly held my attention. And I had fun.\n\nI'd have liked it to be longer, had more maps available, some customization in bending abilities, and a couple lesser nitpicks. But I cannot deny I had a lot of fun with this one. It's colorful, it's fairly intuitive (target select notwithstanding), and short as it may be, I find it very satisfying. It exceded my expectations, even if I still got an expectedly casual game. I never tire of running chapter 3 on extreme.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Needs more cabbages.


If you're not an ATLA or TLOK fan I'd probably say move along, but for those who are this game is quite enjoyable.  It's not perfect, but given it's price, it's hardly a bad game - I'd definitely recommend if you catch it on sale.

Combat is fairly decent, and quite fun against groups of standard enemies.  The difficulty curve however is quite high between standard fights and boss fights.  Bosses even on the 'middle' difficulty (hardest available at start) require lots of timed dodges, blocks and counters rather than all out attacks - non-human bosses are impossible to beat without countering, so if you hate the type of game that requires a lot of it, you're not going to have a fun time with this.  Fights against standard enemies are quite fun however, and once you unlock and upgrade the other elements, combat becomes quite enjoyable against hordes of enemies.

Naga levels are well... meh

Visually, the game does a great job of replecating the art style and some of the attacks from the show.

Story wise, the beginning is a bit cliche - protagonist loses powers, has to relearn them, etc. etc. - however, endgame is rather satisfying and fits fairly well with the existing Avatar universe and lore.  Could have used a few occasional cameos from a few primary and tertiary characters (possibly as backup in fights like in the show) to spice up the story/gameplay/cutscenes a little.

Pro-bending mode is quite fun, and is fairly challenging on the highest difficulty.  However, it would have been nice if there was an included arcade fight mode, where you could fight relentless hordes of enemies and see how high you could chain your combos.

Overall, not a perfect game, but a solid game that will be enjoyable for fans of the franchise.
